Award.AwardTitle: AGS-PRF: Changing Sources of Sea-salt Aerosol in Polar Regions: Climate Change Feedbacks and Implications for Atmospheric Oxidative Capacity in a Future, Warmer World
Award.AbstractNarration:
Sea ice is major source of sea salt aerosols in the Polar Regions that occurs by complex wind driven lofting of saline frost flowers and snow. These processes are complex and neglected in current climate assessments. The observed dramatic retreat of the Arctic sea ice in spring in response to climate change can alter sea salt aerosols fluxes underscoring the need to include them in models. The research will examine this effect using high-resolution coupled climate-chemistry-sea ice models developed by the US and use them to improve IPCC climate assessments.

The project will focus on implementing the open ocean and sea ice sea salt sources in the coupled US climate-sea ice (CESM-CICE4) and 3-D atmospheric chemistry transport model and use it to evaluate the climate and sea salt aerosol feedbacks in polar regions for future climate change scenarios consistent with IPCC AR5 runs. The coupled model will be run at very high resolution (0.5 degree atmosphere and 0.1 degree sea ice) to resolve these processes in detail. In addition to providing the first estimate of the indirect and direct radiative impacts of seas-salt feedbacks the work will also examine the changes in atmospheric chemistry via halogen activation that can alter the oxidative capacity and reactive gases in future climate states.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Earth's polar regions (the Arctic and Antarctic) are especially vulnerable to climate change. In this project, I investigated one way that sea ice (frozen seawater floating on the ocean) affects the climate in polar regions that has not been previously considered. The surface of sea ice is salty, so snow that falls on top of sea ice can wick up salty brine and becomes salty as well. Under the right conditions, wind can lift up the salty snow and release sea salt particles into the air ("blowing snow sea salt"). These particles impact the climate by reflecting sunlight away and by helping to form clouds, which may trap warmth below them when it's dark or reflect sunlight away when it's light. They can also affect the chemistry of greenhouse gases including methane. As the Earth warms under climate change, sea ice changes as well. I developed an open-source climate model, the Community Earth System Model, to include blowing snow sea salt particles and to estimate their impact on polar climate today and in the future as the climate changes. Including this previously-missing process will improve our understanding of polar climate and our predictions of future climate change.

I found that the salt content of surface snow on top of sea ice is key to determining how the emissions of sea salt from blowing snow may change in the future. I analyzed data of the salt content of snow on top of sea ice in both polar regions. From this, I created a set of equations describing how the surface snow salt content depends on 1) the depth of snow and 2) the salt content of the surface of the sea ice below. This will allow climate models to represent how snow salt content changes with changing sea ice and snow properties. My data analysis also suggests that Antarctic surface snow salt content may be much higher than previously thought after taking into account more recent and extensive observations. This would change our understanding of blowing snow sea salt emissions in Antarctica. 

From my climate model results, I found that blowing snow sea salt particles change clouds in the Arctic, including increasing the amount of sunlight reflected away from earth and increasing how much heat is trapped below clouds during the winter months. Similar but smaller changes are seen over Antarctica. These could lead to significant changes in the overall radiative balance in polar regions, influencing both our understanding of present-day climate in the cold season and future climate change. I also found that the spatial patterns and amount of blowing snow sea salt emissions are affected by uncertainties in meteorology (e.g., air temperature). As a result, I developed model studies to quantify these effects, including how wind gusts are represented.

The additions to the open-source climate model from this work will be made freely available to the community, promoting future scientific research. Related to this project, content was developed for a planetarium show at the Pacific Science Center in Seattle focused on polar science. The show is open to the public of all ages. Finally, this project supported increasing the participation of women in STEM. I advised two undergraduate women on related scientific research during this award, which included teaching them computer programming for the first time and how to use and analyze global computer models, as well as mentoring them on pathways to careers in science. Both wrote successful senior theses on their results, and one is currently being prepared for publication. This award funded one of the students as an intern at the Joint Institute of the Study of the Atmosphere and Ocean (JISAO) Research Experience for Undergraduates, which aims to support diverse students who do not have access to research opportunities at their home institutions.
